required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Pawsitive Impacts of Therapy Dog Visits
clinical_study.official_title: A Study of the Pawsitive Impacts of Therapy Dog Visits With Adult Emergency Department Pain Patients

brief_summary.textblock: The goal of this unique 18 month study is to better understand the experiences of pain patients in the Royal University Hospital (RUH) Emergency Department (ED), to create excellence in health care. The purpose is to measure the impact of visiting therapy dogs on reducing ED patient pain.

detailed_description.textblock:
The goal of this unique 18 month study is to better understand the experiences of pain patients in the Royal University Hospital (RUH) Emergency Department (ED), to create excellence in health care. The purpose is to measure the impact of visiting therapy dogs on reducing ED patient pain.
The background rationale is that pain is the primary reason individuals attend an ED, patient pain is generally not well managed in EDs, Saskatchewan EDs have among the longest wait times in the country, and anxiety associated with ED waiting can negatively impact patients' pain.
Research suggests a therapy dog can change patients' perceptions of pain and its intensity and facilitate relaxation. The intervention will be examined for its impact on patients' sensory pain (i.e., physical pain severity), affective pain (i.e., emotional pain unpleasantness) and anxiety.
It is important to find creative, low-cost ways to respond to patients attending the ED for pain. The primary objective of this study is to generate new health-related knowledge on the ED pain patient experience. The secondary objectives are to implement effective end-of-grant knowledge translation and dissemination strategies and undertake a successful model of collaborative, multidisciplinary research among researchers, patient advisors and system representatives, rooted in a One Health framework.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Data is to be collected 5 days a week, with animal testing days alternating with control days.
study_design_info.masking_description: Consent will be obtained using a deceptive consent form, which will explain that this is a pain study, but will omit any information regarding therapy dogs. Once all measures are taken, the participants will be explained the deception and asked to sign the true consent form.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants Stratified by Edmonton Symptom Assessment System (Revised Version) (ESAS-r) Pain Scores
primary_outcome.description: Participants Stratified by Pain scores Edmonton Symptom Assessment System (revised version) (ESAS-r) 11-point rating scale (scale of 0 to 10), in which higher ratings indicate worse outcomes, Pain Scores at 20 Minutes Post Visit.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline visit compared to 20 minutes post-visit
primary_outcome.description: Pain score using the Edmonton Symptom Assessment System (revised version) (ESAS-r) 11-point rating scale (scale of 0 to 10), in which higher ratings indicate worse outcomes.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants Stratified by Edmonton Symptom Assessment System (Revised Version) (ESAS-r) Anxiety Scores
secondary_outcome.description: Participants Stratified by Edmonton Symptom Assessment System (revised version) (ESAS-r) 11-point rating scale (scale of 0 to 10), in which higher ratings indicate worse outcomes, Anxiety Scores at 20 Minutes Post Visit

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants Stratified by Edmonton Symptom Assessment System (Revised Version) (ESAS-r) Depression Scores
secondary_outcome.description: Participants Stratified by Edmonton Symptom Assessment System (revised version) (ESAS-r) 11-point rating scale (scale of 0 to 10), in which higher ratings indicate worse outcomes, Depression Scores at 20 Minutes Post Visit

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants Stratified by Edmonton Symptom Assessment System (Revised Version) (ESAS-r) Well-Being Scores
secondary_outcome.description: Participants Stratified by Edmonton Symptom Assessment System (revised version) (ESAS-r) 11-point rating scale (scale of 0 to 10), in which higher ratings indicate worse outcomes, Well-being Scores at 20 Minutes Post Visit.
Mean arterial blood pressure using a blood pressure cuff

arm_group.description: Patient interacts with the therapy dog and handler.
No patient interaction with the therapy dog or handler.

intervention.description: For the intervention group, patient interacts with the therapy dog, handler shares information about the therapy dog, asks about patient's pets, and offers a trading card of the therapy dog at the conclusion of the visit.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Over the age of 18
- Able to provide consent
- Attending the Emergency Department because of pain/discomfort
- Canadian Triage and Acuity Score (CTAS) of 2-5
- Willing to visit with a therapy dog team (intervention group only)
Exclusion Criteria:
- Pain medications (specifically immediate release acetaminophen and opioid analgesics) within an hour prior to the visit

responsible_party.investigator_title: Research Chair in One Health & Wellness, Professor, Tenured

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Recruitment took place at the Emergency Department of the Royal University Hospital in Saskatoon, SK, between June and September of 2019.

reported_events.desc: Death, serious adverse effects, and other (non-serious adverse effects) were not assessed for this study. An intervention of interaction with a therapy dog is not expected to put participants at risk of Serious Adverse Events, All-Cause Mortality, or Other.

group.title: Therapy Dog Team Visit
group.description: Patient interacts with the therapy dog and handler. Therapy Dog Team Visit: For the intervention group, patient interacts with the therapy dog, handler shares information about the therapy dog, asks about patient's pets, and offers a trading card of the therapy dog at the conclusion of the visit.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.

clinical_results.limitations_and_caveats: Did not account for impact of handlers in therapy dog visits Power analysis and larger sample needed to examine interaction of key demographic independent variables - dog experience and intersecting identity factors (ethnicity and age) Intervention group of human visitation without dog not included Limited to one hospital setting Did not ask about medications taken at home that may have influenced pain scores Various variables can influence blood pressure and heart rate
